Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2010 08:48PM CaseyDoodle wrote: I have come to hate hearing people complain about having birthdays.  I know it is petty, but I just can't help it.  I do understand that people don't like to let go of their youth, but what the h*ll?  It beats the alternative right??.  Don't complain to me about being another year older - it's a blessing!!!  Celebrate your birthday and shut up - or don't celebrate and let it pass without notice, just don't WHINE about it!!! OK, thanks.  I feel better now....
Posts.Title: You know what I hate...rant! everyminute cherneski

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 08:59AM CaseyDoodle wrote: Momof6 and Dealite2007,  I am sorry that both of you have found yourselves here.  I hope that you are able to find the support that you need.  My fellow survivors are very knowledgeable and caring and I'm sure many will have words of wisdom for you. I was diagnosed on April 8, 2008, after having my annual mammogram on March 6, 2008.  It was the longest month I have ever lived through.  After the mammogram, I had a second mammogram, then an ultrasound, then an MRI, then meeting with the surgeon.  Along the way, I was told that they weren's sure whether the tumor had pierced my chest wall, which was doubly scarey.  I thought it would never end.  It was the agony of waiting one week at a time and then only getting one more piece of the puzzel.  I actually took my mammogram films and compared them to a film I found on the Mayo Clinic website.  When I saw the similarities between the two, I was sure it was cancer.  The waiting was the hardest part.  Once I knew I had cancer, I knew immediately that I would have a bilateral mastectomy, as I did not want to find myself in the same place again.  Also, my mother died of breast cancer 12 years ago after a 6 year battle.  She was diagnosed at 52, me at 50.  I will agree that staying busy helps and looking forward to the next test, rather than the final diagnosis also helped me.  Also, I made the decision NOW to fight and win, against whatever came my way.  That gave me some peace. I wish I could offer you more comfort.  For now, I will pray for your peace.
Posts.Title: Nodules & Calcifications Momof6 1osugrl

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2009 09:07PM CaseyDoodle wrote: Dealite, My mother had one breast removed.  By the time the doctor's found it again, it was in her bones, liver and brain.  She did not have health insurance and was not treated as she should have been for the cancer.  Not due to the doctors' negligence, but because she couldn't afford it and was too proud to ask for help.  Very, very sad.  After my mastectomy, the BS told me that there were pre-cancerous cells in the right breast, so it is a good thing I had a bilat, or I most certainly would have found myself in the same place again. I hope you end up with a B9 problem without the worries of BC, but know that life goes on after the diagnosis.  Good luck, God speed and stay in touch.
Posts.Title: Nodules & Calcifications Momof6 1osugrl

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2008 12:35PM CaseyDoodle wrote: Here's my story: Finished 6 TX TCH on 9/23/08.  I did get "growth rings" in both my fingernails and toenails, but didn't get black or brown streaks.  I have not lost any so far, but have read that it could take months.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2010 09:32PM - edited Jan 9, 2010 09:32PM by CaseyDoodle Unfortunately, I can't offer any advice regarding medication, but I can tell you that three months into Arimidex, with a lot of walking, my joint pain stopped.  I have knee problems too, so I am very thankful for the relief from the added pain from Arimidex. Good Luck!

Posts.Content: CaseyDoodle wrote: Had my regular mammogram on Thursday, 3/20.  Got the call that there were concerns on Friday.  Follow-up digital mammo and ultrasound on Wednesday, 3/26 at Breast Center.  "Clustered Calcifications" - whatever that means.  Dr. says it's a win-win situation because it's early - didn't show up on mammo last year.  Says it's 1cm in size.  Scheduled for Biopsy on 4/2.  Have worried  for days now.  At 51, I am two years younger than my mother was when she was diagnosed.  She was dead by 57.  The waiting is horrible.  Kay Dx 4/8/2008, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 2, 0/3 nodes, ER+/PR-, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Waiting on Wednesday CaseyDoodle Dukemom2

Posts.Content: Mar 31, 2008 01:06PM CaseyDoodle wrote: Thanks everyone.  I am trying to distract myself today, cleaning out my hobby room (boring!!).  The doctor says there is a 30% chance that it's malignant.  How can they tell that??  All in all, I know the odds aren't bad.  I wish I could just live my life until I get the results.  I know it is a waste of precious time to worry, but my brain won't let it go.  Thanks again.
